nodes.bodyText:
@maheshambule  Is there an analogous command for production environment for this step?
If not to reduce confusion please list the full sequence of steps of Dev and Prod as two separate subsections in the readme.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -48,9 +48,11 @@ NOTE At present, wheels for windows are not available on PyPi. However following
  - Start 'Anaconda Powershell Prompt' (APP) as Admin User i.e. By right click on APP and run following commands
  - `git clone https://github.com/pytorch/serve.git`
  - `pip install click`
- - `cd serve`
- - `python .\ts_scripts\install_dependencies.py`
- - `python .\ts_scripts\install_from_src.py`
+ - `cd serve`  
+ -  for development purposes, use command below:  
+   `python .\ts_scripts\install_dependencies.py --environment=dev`

nodes.bodyText:
Yes. It is there. The param --environment=prod is for production. The default value for environment is 'prod' only.
I have created two subsections to avoid confusion and provided explicit environment param for production.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -48,9 +48,11 @@ NOTE At present, wheels for windows are not available on PyPi. However following
  - Start 'Anaconda Powershell Prompt' (APP) as Admin User i.e. By right click on APP and run following commands
  - `git clone https://github.com/pytorch/serve.git`
  - `pip install click`
- - `cd serve`
- - `python .\ts_scripts\install_dependencies.py`
- - `python .\ts_scripts\install_from_src.py`
+ - `cd serve`  
+ -  for development purposes, use command below:  
+   `python .\ts_scripts\install_dependencies.py --environment=dev`

nodes.bodyText: I had tested with Py37 on conda recently. Why are we adding Py38 as as a min?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -25,42 +25,37 @@ TorchServe is a flexible and easy to use tool for serving PyTorch models.
 
 ## Install TorchServe
 
-1. Install Java 11
+1. Install dependencies
 
-    For Ubuntu
-    ```bash
-    sudo apt-get install openjdk-11-jdk
-    ```
-   
-   For Mac
-    ```bash
-    brew tap AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk
-    brew cask install adoptopenjdk11
-    ```
-
-2. Install python pre-requisite packages
+Note: For Conda, Python 3.8 is required to run Torchserve.
